episode eight we did cave tiles recently a clever guy by the name of Mike majors
posted in DM Scotty's Facebook group his interpretation of them and they're
awesome a couple of very subtle simple tweaks to the design makes for a better
looking and easier to build tile here it is for these tiles the foundations will
always be two and a half light by two and a half light as in episode eight cut
some 1 and 1/8 inch chipboard squares and round off the corners generously
wrap the squares in crinkled tinfoil and hot glue them to the foundation being
sure to leave 1/8 inch gap between them apply corrugation cladding
at this point we'll diverge from episode 8 now our convention has been that our
walls are three quarters of an inch tall these chipboard squares have already
added some height and so if you measure we'll find that our wall pieces only
need to be about 3/8 of an inch so get some single corrugated cardboard and cut
strips that are 3/8 of an inch wide and at least 4 inches long
important note cut against the corrugation now determine how you want
to attach it there are really only three kinds of tiles here a field with no
walls a side wall in which the wall begins and ends at two adjacent corners
and a diagonal wall in which the wall begins and ends at two opposing corners
let's do a side wall Bend increase the wall piece and eyeball where it's going
to go then cut off the excess hot glue it right on top of the squares apply the
hot glue to the cardboard not the squares because that tin foil will cause
the glue to cool much faster you may not have enough time
now apply a small amount of hot glue to the wall and tease it upwards with the
nozzle kind of like a stalagmite look do the same for the other side
and fill in the exposed corrugation with hot glue
now at this point I started basing with black paint but then I had a few other
ideas so I stopped first place some rubble piles with the usual white PVA
glue sand and pebbles do two or three piles per tile and hit both sides of the
wall then cut some half circles out of any kind of card stock about a half inch
across glue up against the wall as shown Chace the perimeter of the half circle
piece with a bead of hot glue this makes sort of a font or a pool now at this
point I figured why not take the opportunity to try something new with
regard to painting so after a lot of experimentation here's what I came up
with base the tile in white then apply a full-coverage coat of a light cream or
beige color I'm using parchment this is essentially just another base coat I
found that using a soft tip brush was better because it doesn't drag paint
along with it nearly as badly it just glides over anything that's already wet
all right now we're going to enter a whole new world we're going to try a
wash don't close the window press me so with the base coats totally dry we're
going to take some burnt umber or any dark brown and we're going to dip the
brush into water and don't squeeze out the excess water pull out some paint and
mix it with the water to make a wash apply the wash to the entire tile you'll
see the paint flowing into all the great detail that you've made and it's a very
satisfying feeling when you get it right getting the right ratio of paint and
water does require a knack but you'll find that you've mastered it in only a
minute or two shown here is kind of the amount of coverage that you're aiming
for the great thing about washes is if it's too light or dark just dab it with
paper towel it comes right off and you can start over so here's the set of
tiles wet just after the wash and here they are dry note that the
color of a wash changes when drying it loses some hue and is generally darker
now we're going to do is apply another wash so make sure that the first one is
totally bone-dry if it's even still a little bit tacky the paint will return
to solution and you'll get a muddled mess so just leave them overnight for
the second wash I'm using a lighter Richard Brown called cocoa bean you can
see the difference between the two on my palette there again mix up a wash but
this time we're not doing full coverage as shown just roughly hit the walls and
kind of sporadically strike at the squares
here they are wet and here they are dry so the result here
is not a sepia ink but it's somewhat decent approximation of it here they are

for those pools that we made against the walls I'm going to put on a thick coat
of midnight blue and then while it's still wet I'm just going to swirl in
some very light blue now once dry I'm going to apply a matte
or satin varnish to cover the entire tile this will protect the paint from
scratching they may look okay right now but that
paint is sitting on tin foil which comes off very easily so this layer of varnish
will protect it finally since these are caverns I thought I'd attach some
exposed gemstones like crystal veins or geodes or something like that

stick to two or three colors to make sure that they complement the pools and

together I sort of was aiming for an under dark look which lately all the

I'm really happy with how these turned out all that detail the tinfoil and hot

round experimenting trying to do my usual base in black and then build the

so these are the first tiles we've done where there's something on the other
